net.happybrackets.core.control

Class IntegerControl

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.happybrackets.core.control.DynamicControlParent
      • net.happybrackets.core.control.IntegerControl
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    IntegerBuddyControl, IntegerSliderControl, IntegerTextControl

    public class IntegerControl
extends DynamicControlParent
    This class encapsulates the functionality of DynamicControl classes of type ControlType.INT in a simple API

    All IntegerControl controls with the same name and ControlScope will respond to a message send. For example: For example, consider two IntegerControls with the same ControlScope and name Setting the value of control1 will cause any objects listening to control1 or control2 to receive the action. EG

    When the control receives the value, it will be passed through to the valueChanged(int) )} listener that is implemented when the class is created.
    For example: 
     IntegerControl control1 = new IntegerControl(this, "Read", 0);

 IntegerControl control2 = new IntegerControl(this, "Read", 0) {
     @Override
    public void valueChanged(int control_val) {
        System.out.println("Read " + control_val);
    }
};

 control1.setValue(2); // this will also set the value of control2

    Will cause the valueChanged(int) function to be called with the new value, causing Read 2 to be printed to standard output. This is because both controls are ControlScope.SKETCH by default and are both have their name as "Read.

    The control can also schedule messages to be sent at a time in the future by adding the time to the message using an absolute time in the setValue(int, double) function. Eg
    control1.setValue (2, HB.getSchedulerTime() + 1000); // this will set control1 value, as well as all other IntegerControl with same ControlScope and name, to true 1 second in the future
    You can also set the value from within the HappyBrackets plugin IDE.
    Additionally, you can get current value by calling the getValue() function. If you require a handler on the class, override the valueChanged(int) function

      • IntegerControl

        public IntegerControl(java.lang.Object parent_sketch,
                      java.lang.String name,
                      int initial_value,
                      int min_val,
                      int max_val,
                      DynamicControl.DISPLAY_TYPE display_type)
        Constructor for IntegerControl if you want it displayed other than text control.
        Parameters:
        parent_sketch - The parent object for control
        name - The name to Display
        initial_value - Initial value of the object
        min_val - Minimum value to display on Slider
        max_val - Maximum value to display on Slider
        display_type - The way we want object displayed

                      java.lang.String name,

        Constructor for abstract IntegerControl. This allows creation without a display
        Parameters:
        parent_sketch - The parent object for control
        name - The name to Display
        initial_value - Initial value of the object

    • Method Detail

      • getValue

        public int getValue()
        Get the value for the control. 
        IntegerControl control1 = new IntegerControl(this, "Read", 0);

IntegerControl control2 = new IntegerControl(this, "Read", 0) {
      @Override
    public void valueChanged(int control_val) {
        System.out.println("Read " + control_val);
    }
};

int val = control1.getValue(); // val = 0
control1.setValue(2);
val = control1.getValue();// val = 1
        Returns:
        the control value

      • valueChanged

        public void valueChanged(int control_val)

        When the control receives the value, it will be passed through to the valueChanged(int) listener that is implemented when the class is created.
        For example 
        IntegerControl control1 = new IntegerControl(this, "Read", 0);

IntegerControl control2 = new IntegerControl(this, "Read", 0) {
     @Override
    public void valueChanged(int control_val) {
        System.out.println("Read " + control_val);
    }
};

control1.setValue(2); // this will also set the value of control2

        Will cause the valueChanged(int) function to be called with the new value, causing Read 2 to be printed to standard output
        Parameters:
        control_val - the value received

      • setValue

        public void setValue(int val)
        set the value for the control. This will pass the message on to all other DynamicControl with matching name, type and ControlScope and call valueChanged(int). 
         IntegerControl control1 = new IntegerControl(this, "Read", 0);

 IntegerControl control2 = new IntegerControl(this, "Read", 0) {
     @Override
    public void valueChanged(int control_val) {
        System.out.println("Read " + control_val);
    }
 };

 control1.setValue(2); // this will also set the value of control2

        Will cause the valueChanged(int) function to be called with the new value, causing Read 2 to be printed to standard output
        Parameters:
        val - the value to set to

      • setValue

        public void setValue(int val,
                     double scheduler_time)
        set the value for the control at a specific time. Identical to the setValue(int) with the exception that the valueChanged(int) event will be caused at the HBScheduler scheduled time passed in.
        For example, the following code will cause matching DynamicControl objects to respond 1 second in the future 
             IntegerControl control1 = new IntegerControl(this, "Read", 0);

     IntegerControl control2 = new IntegerControl(this, "Read", 0) {
         @Override
        public void valueChanged(int control_val) {
        System.out.println("Read " + control_val);
        }
     };

     control1.setValue(2, HB.getSchedulerTime() + 1000); // this will also set the value of control2
        Parameters:
        val - the value to set to
        scheduler_time - the scheduler time this is supposed to occur at

      • setDisplayType

        public IntegerControl setDisplayType(DynamicControl.DISPLAY_TYPE display_type)
        Change how to display object We must do this in subclass
        Parameters:
        display_type - The new Control Scope
        Returns:
        this object

      • setControlScope

        public IntegerControl setControlScope(ControlScope new_scope)
        Changed the ControlScope the object has has. It will update control map so the correct events will be generated based on its scope
        Overrides:
        setControlScope in class DynamicControlParent
        Parameters:
        new_scope - The new Control Scope
        Returns:
        this object

        public IntegerControl setDisplayRange(int minimum,
                                      int maximum,
                                      DynamicControl.DISPLAY_TYPE display_type)
        Set how we want this control displayed
        Parameters:

        maximum - maximum display value on slider
        display_type - the type of display
        Returns:
